episodeTitle: Explosion! The Sunny's Super-Secret Weapon, Gaon Cannon
description: Duval reveals his dramatic backstory and face, which shockingly resembles Sanji's poorly-drawn wanted poster. After a fierce battle where Camie saves Sanji from drowning and the Flying Fish Riders attempt to crush the Thousand Sunny, Franky unveils the ship's secret weapon: the devastating Gaon Cannon. In a surprising moment, Luffy unknowingly uses Conqueror's Haki to stop Duval's charging bull Motobaro. Sanji then transforms Duval's face with his brutal Parage Shot technique, accidentally making him handsome and turning enemies into future allies.

events.title: Duval's Tragic Backstory Revealed
events.description: Duval reveals the truth behind his grudge against Sanji. He was once a peaceful small-time bandit, but when Sanji's poorly-drawn wanted poster was released, Duval's life was ruined. Due to his uncanny resemblance to the poster's illustration, he was constantly pursued by Marines and bounty hunters, forcing him into hiding behind his iron mask.
events.significance: This revelation transforms what seemed like a simple antagonist into a tragic character whose life was destroyed by coincidence. It also provides payoff to the long-running gag about Sanji's awful wanted poster photo, showing how Oda connects humor to plot.

quotes.text: Because of that wanted poster, my peaceful life was destroyed! Marines and bounty hunters chased me everywhere!
quotes.speaker: Duval
quotes.context: Duval explaining how Sanji's wanted poster ruined his life

events.title: Duval's Face Finally Revealed
events.description: After Luffy knocks off Duval's iron mask, his face is finally revealed to the shocked Straw Hats. His face is an exact match for the comically poor illustration on Sanji's wanted poster - except his eyebrow swirls in the opposite direction. The crew's reaction ranges from shock to uncontrollable laughter.
events.significance: This moment is both comedic gold and a major plot reveal. It explains Duval's obsessive hatred of Sanji and provides one of One Piece's most memorable comedic moments. The reveal showcases Oda's ability to make long-term setups pay off in unexpected ways.

quotes.text: That's... that's the face from Sanji's wanted poster! It's real!
quotes.speaker: Usopp
quotes.context: Usopp's shocked reaction to seeing Duval's face

events.title: Duval Attempts to Drown Sanji with Steel Nets
events.description: In his rage, Duval uses steel nets to trap Sanji and pull him underwater, attempting to drown him. Luffy tries to jump in to save Sanji, but Zoro stops him, reminding everyone that Luffy can't swim due to his Devil Fruit powers.
events.significance: This moment demonstrates Duval's desperation for revenge and creates tension in the battle. It also reminds viewers of Luffy's vulnerability to water, a core weakness that makes the situation more dramatic.

quotes.text: Luffy, you can't! You'll sink like a rock!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro stopping Luffy from jumping into the water

events.title: Camie Rescues Sanji from Drowning
events.description: Camie dives into the water after Sanji, using her incredible speed as a mermaid to reach him quickly. She frees him from the steel nets and brings him back to the surface. Sanji immediately gets a massive nosebleed because Camie had pressed his face against her chest while rescuing him.
events.significance: This scene showcases Camie's abilities as a mermaid, demonstrating why mermaids are considered the fastest swimmers in the One Piece world. It also provides classic Sanji comedy with his exaggerated reaction to being saved by a beautiful mermaid.

quotes.text: Even if the Flying Fish Riders and Fish-Men are fast underwater, mermaids are much faster than them!
quotes.speaker: Pappag
quotes.context: Pappag explaining why Camie can save Sanji

events.title: The Gaon Cannon's Devastating Debut
events.description: As the Flying Fish Riders bring up a massive anchor to drop on the Thousand Sunny, Franky announces the ship has a secret weapon. Usopp discovers controls at the bow, and the Sunny's lion figurehead opens to reveal a massive cannon. The Gaon Cannon fires a concentrated air blast that destroys Duval's hideout and scatters the Flying Fish Riders.
events.significance: The debut of the Gaon Cannon showcases the Thousand Sunny's full capabilities as a ship designed by the genius shipwright Franky. This powerful weapon becomes one of the crew's most devastating long-range attacks and demonstrates the ship's superiority over their previous vessel.

quotes.text: This is the Thousand Sunny's super weapon! Gaon Cannon, fire!
quotes.speaker: Franky
quotes.context: Franky announcing and firing the Gaon Cannon for the first time

events.title: Luffy's First Display of Conqueror's Haki
events.description: After the Gaon Cannon's blast, an enraged Duval charges at Luffy riding his bull Motobaro. However, when Motobaro gets close to Luffy, the bull suddenly shakes in fear and collapses unconscious. Luffy didn't physically attack - he unknowingly used Conqueror's Haki (Haoshoku Haki) to intimidate the animal, though neither he nor the crew understand what happened.
events.significance: This is the first visual representation of Luffy using Conqueror's Haki in the anime, though it's played as a comedic moment and not explained until much later. This subtle foreshadowing demonstrates Oda's long-term planning, as the true nature of this power won't be revealed until Amazon Lily and Marineford arcs.

quotes.text: What just happened? I didn't even touch it!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy confused about why Motobaro collapsed

events.title: Sanji's Parage Shot Face Reconstruction
events.description: Furious about having to see his 'wanted poster face' in real life, Sanji launches a brutal series of targeted kicks to specific parts of Duval's face: Oeil (eye), Nez (nose), Joue (cheek), Bouche (mouth), Dents (teeth), and Menton (chin), finishing with Parage Shot. The violent 'plastic surgery' completely restructures Duval's facial bones.
events.significance: The Parage Shot technique showcases Sanji's incredible precision and power, demonstrating he can target specific points with surgical accuracy. This technique's name comes from 'parage,' referring to the process of rearranging facial structure, essentially being violent cosmetic surgery.

quotes.text: I'm going to fix that face! Parage Shot!
quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji launching his finishing move on Duval's face

events.title: Duval Transformed into a Handsome Man
events.description: After Sanji's Parage Shot, Duval's face is completely changed. Instead of resembling the ugly wanted poster, he's now extremely handsome with chiseled features. Duval is overjoyed with his new appearance, crying tears of gratitude rather than anger. The transformation marks the end of hostilities.
events.significance: This transformation resolves the conflict in an unexpected way - through accidental kindness rather than defeat. It sets up Duval's transition from enemy to ally and shows how the Straw Hats can turn antagonists into friends through unintended consequences.

quotes.text: This face... it's beautiful! Thank you, Sanji!
quotes.speaker: Duval
quotes.context: Duval's emotional reaction to his new handsome face

events.title: Birth of the Future Rosy Life Riders
events.description: With Duval's transformation complete and his grudge resolved, he and his crew decide to abandon their kidnapping operations. Though not yet renamed, this marks the beginning of their transformation from the villainous Flying Fish Riders into the allied Rosy Life Riders.
events.significance: This moment sets up the crew's future role as allies to the Straw Hats. The Flying Fish Riders' reformation demonstrates the Straw Hats' influence in changing people's lives for the better, even their enemies.

quotes.text: Because of that wanted poster, my peaceful life was destroyed! Marines and bounty hunters chased me everywhere!
quotes.speaker: Duval
quotes.context: Duval explaining how Sanji's wanted poster ruined his life

quotes.text: That's... that's the face from Sanji's wanted poster! It's real!
quotes.speaker: Usopp
quotes.context: Usopp's shocked reaction to seeing Duval's face

quotes.text: Even if the Flying Fish Riders and Fish-Men are fast underwater, mermaids are much faster than them!
quotes.speaker: Pappag
quotes.context: Pappag explaining why Camie can save Sanji

quotes.text: This is the Thousand Sunny's super weapon! Gaon Cannon, fire!
quotes.speaker: Franky
quotes.context: Franky announcing and firing the Gaon Cannon for the first time

quotes.text: What just happened? I didn't even touch it!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy confused about why Motobaro collapsed

quotes.text: I'm going to fix that face! Parage Shot!
quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji launching his finishing move on Duval's face

quotes.text: This face... it's beautiful! Thank you, Sanji!
quotes.speaker: Duval
quotes.context: Duval's emotional reaction to his new handsome face

themes.description: The episode explores how random chance can dramatically alter someone's life. Duval's resemblance to a poorly-drawn wanted poster wasn't his fault, yet it destroyed his peaceful existence. This theme examines how one person's action (or in this case, a photographer's mistake) can have unforeseen consequences for another.
themes.symbolism: Duval's iron mask symbolizes hiding from fate and consequences you didn't deserve. His unmasking represents confronting the truth, no matter how absurd.

themes.description: What could be a purely tragic story - a man's life ruined by mistaken identity - is transformed into one of One Piece's most comedic moments. The revelation that the 'poster face' exists in reality turns a serious grudge into absurdist humor.
themes.symbolism: The contrast between Duval's serious rage and the ridiculous reason behind it reflects One Piece's ability to blend comedy and drama seamlessly.

themes.description: Through violence meant as revenge, Sanji accidentally grants Duval's deepest wish - freedom from his cursed face. This unintended act of kindness transforms an enemy into an ally, showing how even destructive actions can lead to positive outcomes.
themes.symbolism: Duval's facial transformation represents a rebirth and second chance at life. The Parage Shot literally reconstructs his identity.
culturalReferences: The concept of 'kintsugi' - finding beauty and value through transformation and repair

themes.description: The episode demonstrates how wanted posters and bounties affect lives beyond their intended targets. Duval's story shows the collateral damage of the World Government's bounty system.
themes.symbolism: The wanted poster becomes a curse that haunts an innocent man, representing how labels and reputations can control lives.

characterSpotlights.development: Duval's backstory transforms him from a mysterious masked villain into a sympathetic character whose life was destroyed by circumstances beyond his control. His transformation - both physical and emotional - from bitter enemy to grateful ally showcases character depth and the episode's theme of redemption.
keyActions: Reveals his tragic backstory about resembling Sanji's wanted poster
Removes his iron mask to show his face
Attempts to drown Sanji with steel nets
Charges at Luffy on Motobaro
Receives Sanji's Parage Shot and is transformed
Becomes grateful and friendly toward the Straw Hats
quotes: Because of that wanted poster, my peaceful life was destroyed! Marines and bounty hunters chased me everywhere!
This face... it's beautiful! Thank you, Sanji!

characterSpotlights.development: Sanji goes from being annoyed by Duval's grudge to being absolutely horrified that the 'poster face' exists in reality. His use of Parage Shot shows his precision combat skills, and his accidental creation of a handsome face demonstrates how his actions have unintended positive consequences.
keyActions: Learns he's responsible for ruining Duval's life
Gets trapped in steel nets and nearly drowns
Is rescued by Camie (leading to massive nosebleed)
Unleashes Parage Shot to 'fix' Duval's face
Accidentally makes Duval handsome
quotes: I'm going to fix that face! Parage Shot!

characterSpotlights.development: Franky demonstrates his genius as a shipwright by revealing the Thousand Sunny's hidden superweapon. His pride in his creation and perfect timing showcase his value to the crew.
keyActions: Announces the Sunny has a secret weapon
Coordinates with Usopp to operate the Gaon Cannon
Successfully destroys Duval's hideout with the first shot
quotes: This is the Thousand Sunny's super weapon! Gaon Cannon, fire!

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy unknowingly displays Conqueror's Haki for the first time in a visible way, though it's played for comedy. His confusion about what happened shows he's not yet aware of this power.
keyActions: Knocks off Duval's iron mask
Reacts with shock to Duval's face
Unknowingly uses Conqueror's Haki to knock out Motobaro
Remains confused about his own power
quotes: What just happened? I didn't even touch it!

characterSpotlights.development: Camie demonstrates her abilities as a mermaid, showing why her species is considered the fastest swimmers in the world. Her brave rescue of Sanji reinforces her kind nature.
keyActions: Dives into the water to save Sanji
Uses her mermaid speed to reach him quickly
Frees Sanji from the steel nets
Brings him safely to the surface

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extended the Gaon Cannon sequence with more dramatic buildup and visual effects, including detailed shots of the cannon's mechanisms opening.
The anime added more comedic reactions from the Straw Hats when Duval's face is revealed, with extended facial expressions and dialogue.
Sanji's Parage Shot sequence was extended in the anime with more detailed animation of each individual kick and its effect on Duval's face.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts portions of manga Chapters 494 (pages 17, 19) and 495 (pages 2-19), titled 'Duval's Tragedy' and 'Gaon Cannon' respectively.
This episode marks the first clear visual representation of Luffy using Conqueror's Haki in the anime, though it wouldn't be explained or named until the Amazon Lily arc over 20 episodes later.

sources.title: Haki/Supreme King Haki - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The Funimation English dub mistakenly refers to the Gaon Cannon as 'Chicken Voyage,' a mistranslation that became a source of humor among English-speaking fans.
The names of Sanji's kicks in the Parage Shot sequence are all French words for facial features: Oeil (eye), Nez (nose), Joue (cheek), Bouche (mouth), Dents (teeth), and Menton (chin).

sources.title: Black Leg Style - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Episode 389 received a TV rating of 8.4%, ranking it as the 5th highest-rated episode of that broadcast week in Japan.
The Gaon Cannon is named after the Japanese onomatopoeia 'gaon' (ガオン), which represents a massive roaring or booming sound, fitting for the cannon's powerful blast.
Duval's character design before and after the Parage Shot showcases Oda's art range - from deliberately ugly to bishōnen (beautiful male) style, demonstrating his versatility in character design.
This episode aired in Japan on February 15, 2009, but didn't reach US audiences via Funimation DVD until July 14, 2015 - over 6 years later.
